content.title: Central Line-Associated Bloodstream Infection Prevention
content.summary: CLABSI prevention bundles combine evidence-based insertion and maintenance practices to prevent bloodstream infections from central venous catheters, including hand hygiene, maximal sterile barriers, chlorhexidine skin prep, optimal site selection, and daily line necessity review.
key_points: CLABSI causes 12-25% attributable mortality and adds $25,000-50,000 per infection
Insertion bundle: hand hygiene, full barrier precautions, chlorhexidine skin prep, avoid femoral site, remove unnecessary lines
Maintenance bundle: daily review of line necessity, chlorhexidine-impregnated dressings, minimize line manipulation
Subclavian site has lowest infection rate but highest mechanical complication rate
Daily review with prompt removal of unnecessary lines is most effective prevention strategy
Zero CLABSI is achievable with high-reliability bundle implementation
content.statement: Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) prevention is achieved through rigorous adherence to evidence-based insertion and maintenance bundles, including aseptic technique, optimal site selection, chlorhexidine-based skin antisepsis, and systematic daily assessment of line necessity for prompt removal when no longer needed.

explanation.intuition: Central lines breach the skin barrier and provide a direct path for bacteria to enter the bloodstream. Bacteria can contaminate the line during insertion, migrate along the catheter from skin, or seed the catheter hub from handling. Prevention targets each pathway: sterile insertion, skin antisepsis, hub hygiene, and minimizing catheter days.
explanation.key_insight: The most impactful intervention is removing unnecessary lines - every catheter day is a day of infection risk. Rather than just focusing on insertion technique, the cultural shift to 'do we still need this line today?' fundamentally changes CLABSI rates.
explanation.technical_details: CLABSI is defined as laboratory-confirmed BSI in patient with CVC at time of or within 48h before infection onset without other apparent source. NHSN surveillance definitions standardize reporting. Infection rates expressed as infections per 1000 catheter-days. Chlorhexidine >0.5% with alcohol is preferred skin prep; 2% chlorhexidine-impregnated dressings reduce infection further. Antimicrobial-impregnated catheters (chlorhexidine/silver sulfadiazine or minocycline/rifampin) reduce infection in high-risk settings.

definitions_glossary.central_line_associated_bloodstream_infe: Laboratory-confirmed BSI occurring in patient with central line in place at time of or within 48h before infection onset, without other apparent source
definitions_glossary.central_venous_catheter: Catheter terminating in great vessel (SVC, IVC) used for infusion, hemodynamic monitoring, or vascular access
definitions_glossary.insertion_bundle: Set of evidence-based practices performed during catheter insertion to prevent infection
definitions_glossary.maintenance_bundle: Ongoing practices for catheter care after insertion to prevent infection
definitions_glossary.maximal_sterile_barriers: Full drape covering patient, sterile gown and gloves, mask, and cap for inserter and assistants
definitions_glossary.chlorhexidine_skin_prep: Chlorhexidine gluconate >0.5% with alcohol applied to skin before insertion; superior to povidone-iodine
definitions_glossary.catheter_days: Cumulative days of central line presence; denominator for CLABSI rate calculation
definitions_glossary.line_necessity_review: Daily assessment of whether central line is still clinically required
definitions_glossary.hub_contamination: Bacterial colonization of catheter hub from handling; major source of CLABSI
definitions_glossary.antimicrobial_impregnated_catheter: Catheters coated with antimicrobial agents to reduce colonization and infection
definitions_glossary.chlorhexidine_dressing: Transparent dressing impregnated with chlorhexidine for ongoing skin antisepsis
definitions_glossary.zero_harm: Quality improvement goal of eliminating all preventable harm events including CLABSI

infection_routes.extraluminal: Migration of skin organisms along external catheter surface into bloodstream
infection_routes.intraluminal: Contamination of catheter hub during access; bacteria travel through lumen
infection_routes.hematogenous: Seeding of catheter from distant infection site

pathophysiology.biofilm_formation: Bacteria adhere to catheter and form protective biofilm matrix resistant to antibiotics and immune defenses
pathophysiology.risk_timeline: Extraluminal predominates early (<10 days); intraluminal (hub) more common later

epidemiology.incidence: 0.5-3 per 1000 catheter-days in ICU with good prevention programs; historically 5-10+
epidemiology.pathogens: Coagulase-negative staphylococci (30%), S. aureus (20%), Enterococcus (10%), Gram-negatives (20%), Candida (10%)
epidemiology.mortality: Attributable mortality 12-25%; higher with certain organisms (S. aureus, Candida)

insertion_bundle.hand_hygiene: Thorough hand washing or alcohol-based hand rub before donning sterile gear

maximal_sterile_barriers.components: Cap, mask, sterile gown, sterile gloves, large sterile drape covering patient
maximal_sterile_barriers.evidence: Reduces infection 6-fold compared to limited barriers

chlorhexidine_skin_antisepsis.agent: Chlorhexidine >0.5% with alcohol; apply with friction, allow to dry
chlorhexidine_skin_antisepsis.evidence: Superior to povidone-iodine for preventing colonization and infection

optimal_site_selection.subclavian: Lowest infection rate; higher pneumothorax risk; preferred for non-emergent access
optimal_site_selection.internal_jugular: Moderate infection risk; ultrasound guidance reduces mechanical complications
optimal_site_selection.femoral: Highest infection rate; acceptable in emergency; remove as soon as alternative available

insertion_bundle.avoid_unnecessary_lines: Question indication before insertion; use peripheral access when possible

daily_line_review.practice: Ask daily 'Is this line still necessary?' with checklist or nursing prompt
daily_line_review.evidence: Single most effective intervention; every additional catheter-day increases infection risk

dressing_care.transparent_dressing: Change every 5-7 days or when soiled/loose
dressing_care.chlorhexidine_dressing: Reduces CLABSI by ~50%; consider for high-risk patients or units
dressing_care.gauze_dressing: Change every 2 days; use when CHG dressing contraindicated

hub_care.scrub_the_hub: Friction scrub with alcohol or CHG for 10-15 seconds before each access
hub_care.needleless_connectors: Use designated connectors with proper disinfection technique

antimicrobial_catheters.indications: Expected duration >5 days, high CLABSI rate despite bundle compliance
antimicrobial_catheters.evidence: Reduces infection; cost-effective in high-incidence settings

special_considerations.chlorhexidine_bathing: Daily CHG bathing of ICU patients reduces colonization and may reduce CLABSI
special_considerations.antibiotic_lock: Prophylactic antibiotic lock solutions for high-risk long-term catheters (dialysis, oncology)

implementation.bundle_compliance: All-or-none compliance tracking; partial implementation reduces effectiveness
implementation.insertion_checklist: Standardized checklist with empowerment to stop procedure for violations
implementation.audit_feedback: Regular feedback on CLABSI rates and bundle compliance to clinical teams
implementation.zero_culture: Organizational commitment to zero CLABSI as achievable goal

skos.definition: A multimodal bundle of evidence-based insertion and maintenance practices designed to prevent bloodstream infections associated with central venous catheters.

icd10.display: Bloodstream infection due to central venous catheter, initial encounter

learning_objectives: List the components of the CLABSI insertion bundle
Compare infection rates by central line insertion site
Describe daily maintenance practices to prevent CLABSI
Apply quality improvement principles to achieve zero CLABSI
clinical_pearls: The best way to prevent CLABSI is to remove unnecessary lines - ask daily 'Is this line still needed?'
Subclavian has lowest infection rate but highest pneumothorax risk - choose based on patient factors
Scrub the hub for 10-15 seconds before every line access - hub contamination is a major CLABSI source
Chlorhexidine-impregnated dressings reduce CLABSI by ~50% - use in high-risk patients
Empower nurses to stop procedures if sterile technique is broken - creates culture of safety
Zero CLABSI is achievable with high-reliability bundle implementation - don't accept infections as inevitable

board_yield.usmle_step1: Biofilm formation, pathogen characteristics, chlorhexidine mechanism
board_yield.usmle_step2: Bundle components, site selection, sterile technique
board_yield.abim_critical_care: Surveillance definitions, antimicrobial catheter indications, outbreak investigation

common_misconceptions: Misconception: Some CLABSI is inevitable. Reality: Zero CLABSI is achievable with high bundle compliance
Misconception: Femoral is acceptable for routine use. Reality: Should be removed as soon as alternative access available
Misconception: Bundle is mainly about insertion technique. Reality: Daily line necessity review and maintenance are equally important

evidence.confidence_rationale: Strong evidence base with landmark trials demonstrating dramatic infection reduction
